Award.AwardTitle: NSF Conference Grant to Support the 2018 Ciliate Molecular Biology Meeting; July 17-22, 2018, Washington, D.C.

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support early career researcher attendance at the 19th conference on Ciliate Molecular Biology, which will be at the American University campus in Washington D.C. on July 17-22 of 2018. The format of the meeting is a combination of talks and posters, which will promote scientific exchange in both formal and informal settings. One session is devoted to undergraduate research talks and another session is devoted to the integration of ciliate research and teaching. A workshop between sessions focuses on the professional development and mentoring of early career scientists. There will be ample opportunity for sharing the latest research results and for networking.

The conference participants use ciliates as models to investigate diverse questions in cell biology, molecular evolution, structural biology and nucleic acid biochemistry. The structure of the meeting provides both breadth and depth to the scientific communications. The objectives of the conference are the following: (1) support and mentor early career scientist; (2) encourage interdisciplinary research; (3) integrate research and education focused science; (4) develop and share technical innovations; (5) develop community resources.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
On July 17-22, 2018, 108 Ciliate Molecular Biologists from 10 countries convened at the American University campus in Washington DC to present and discuss their science associated with the molecular biology of ciliates. The attendance of early career US scientists to this biannual conference was generously supported by the National Science Foundation (NSF) and additional private foundations. The funding was essential to ensure that the meeting was attended by a diverse community of researchers and teachers focused on Ciliate Molecular Biology. Dr. Boris Striepen (UPenn) opened the meeting with a Keynote address that set the tone for high quality and exploratory science. Over the remaining five days, attendees participated in nine platform sessions covering diverse topics in ciliate molecular biology, two poster sessions and numerous breakout sessions focused on improving resources for early career investigators (discussed below). A major aspect of the Ciliate Molecular Biology community is the inclusion of undergraduate researchers in the meeting. We had a successful platform session where undergraduate researchers presented their research to the diverse group of ciliate researchers. We anticipate that the high-level presentations by these students will strengthen the potential to pursue future STEM research, perhaps in field including ciliate molecular biology.

            The focus of NSF funding for this meeting was to (i) support and mentor early career scientist (ii) encourage interdisciplinary research, (iii) integrate research and education focused science (iv) develop and share technical innovations (v) develop community resources. To achieve these goals, we established a meeting program that promotes each of these five concepts in addition to the general goal of discussing ciliate molecular biology research. A combination of oral presentations, poster sessions, workshops, and breakout sessions were used be used to accomplish these objectives as outlined below. Moreover, we developed a questionnaire to solicit feedback from meeting attendees. This feedback will be used to further support the goals and programs for the next Ciliate Molecular Biology meeting. The 2020 Ciliate Molecular Biology meeting will be held in Lisbon, Portugal.
